content:
This is a question about endofunctors on FinSet, but I think it will be easier if we work with a skeleton F\mathsf{F}F of FinSet. So let's say F\mathsf{F}F is the category with one object

n:={0,1,…,n−1} n := \{0,1,\dots, n-1\}n:={0,1,…,n−1}

for each natural number, and all functions between these finite sets as morphisms.

Question. Is there an endofunctor g:F→Fg: \mathsf{F} \to \mathsf{F}g:F→F which on objects works like this:

g(n)=1 g(n) = 1 g(n)=1 if n<3n \lt 3n<3

g(n)=2g(n) = 2g(n)=2 if n≥3n \ge 3n≥3

?

(I doubt using the number 333 is very important, but I wanted a small number bigger than 111 and I didn't want to use 222 because we're already using that for something else.)

Some motivation: talking to @Tobias Fritz here, I got interested in this question: for which sequences ana_nan​ of natural numbers is there a functor g:F→Fg: \mathsf{F} \to \mathsf{F}g:F→F with g(n)=ang(n) = a_ng(n)=an​?

In an offhand remark on Mathstodon, Bartosz Milewski guessed that such a functor always exists. I asked him if there is a functor ggg with

g(n)=1g(n) = 1g(n)=1 if n=100n = 100n=100
g(n)=0g(n) = 0g(n)=0 otherwise

and he agreed that no such functor exists. That got me interested in some other examples.

I just got up a few minutes ago, so this might affect the quality, but if 2=(0→1)\mathbf{2} = (0 \to 1)2=(0→1) is the walking arrow, then the evident inclusion 2↪F\mathbf{2} \hookrightarrow \mathsf{F}2↪F has a left adjoint that sends a finite set nnn to the image of n→1n \to 1n→1. Let MMM be the monad on F\mathsf{F}F obtained by composing these functors. It should remind you of the Heaviside function.

Let I=Inj(3,−):F→FI = \mathrm{Inj}(3, -): \mathsf{F} \to \mathsf{F}I=Inj(3,−):F→F be the functor that takes a finite set nnn to the set of injective functions 3→n3 \to n3→n. Then form this composite:

F→IF→MF→(−)+1F.\mathsf{F} \overset{I}{\to} \mathsf{F} \overset{M}{\to} \mathsf{F} \overset{(-)+1}{\to} \mathsf{F}.F→IF→MF→(−)+1F.

I think this should do the trick.

How is III a functor on F\mathsf{F}F? We have Inj(3,3)=3!\mathrm{Inj}(3, 3) = 3!Inj(3,3)=3! but Inj(3,1)=∅\mathrm{Inj}(3, 1) = \varnothingInj(3,1)=∅, so there can be no way to interpret IpIpIp for p:3→1p: 3 \to 1p:3→1 the only function of its type.

I do not have an example of a counterexample for the specific question that John is asking, but I have thought of some constraints.

One simple observation is that because all epimorphisms/monomorphisms between non-empty sets in F\mathsf{F}F are split, they must be preserved by ggg. And because in F\mathsf{F}F there exists a (split) mono from nnn to mmm if and only if n≤mn \leq mn≤m, it follows that n↦g(n)n \mapsto g(n)n↦g(n) must be a non-decreasing sequence for all n≥1n \geq 1n≥1.

A less obvious constraint (if I haven't made a mistake in my argument) is the following:

If n≥5n \geq 5n≥5 and g(n)<ng(n) < ng(n)<n, then g(m)=g(n)g(m) = g(n)g(m)=g(n) for all m≥n−2m \geq n - 2m≥n−2.

That is, any endofunctor whose associated sequence does not satisfy n≤g(n)n \leq g(n)n≤g(n) for all n≥5n \geq 5n≥5 must be “eventually constant”, starting from n−2n - 2n−2 where nnn is such that g(n)<ng(n) < ng(n)<n.
This does not exclude John's example -- but it would exclude any variation in which the nnn at which the value changes is strictly larger than 3...

(ERRATA For now I have an argument only for something weaker, see later messages)
I like your "simple observation", Amar. In my conversation with Tobias we naturally gravitated to nondecreasing sequences, but now I know better why!

The argument is the following.
By restricting to just the automorphisms of nnn, every such endofunctor defines a sequence of group homomorphisms Aut(n)=Sn→Sg(n)=Aut(g(n))\mathrm{Aut}(n) = S_n \to S_{g(n)} = \mathrm{Aut}(g(n))Aut(n)=Sn​→Sg(n)​=Aut(g(n)).

I know that there are nontrivial homomorphisms Sn→SmS_n \to S_mSn​→Sm​ with m<nm < nm<n only for m=2m = 2m=2 (for all nnn) and m=3m = 3m=3 (for n=4n = 4n=4). But I haven't put this to use yet to understand what you're claiming. I'd love to use this juicy fact for something.

Suppose g(n)<ng(n) < ng(n)<n. Then the homomorphism Sn→Sg(n)S_n \to S_{g(n)}Sn​→Sg(n)​ cannot be injective, so it must have non-trivial kernel. If n≥5n \geq 5n≥5, the only non-trivial normal subgroups of SnS_nSn​ are the entire group and the alternating group AnA_nAn​. So ggg must take any even permutation of nnn to the identity of g(n)g(n)g(n).

So suppose n≥5n \geq 5n≥5 and g(n)<ng(n) < ng(n)<n and consider an injection i:n−2→n−1i: n -2 \to n-1i:n−2→n−1.
Then, take a surjective map p:n−1→n−2p: n-1 \to n-2p:n−1→n−2 which only identifies two elements of n−1n-1n−1, and let f=i∘pf = i \circ pf=i∘p, a function n−1→n−1n - 1 \to n - 1n−1→n−1.

I claim that we can factorise fff as an injective map j:n−1→nj: n-1 \to nj:n−1→n followed by a surjective map q:n→n−1q: n \to n-1q:n→n−1, and we can find an even permutation σ\sigmaσ of nnn such that q∘σ∘jq \circ \sigma \circ jq∘σ∘j is an isomorphism.

(Basically, jjj only misses one element of nnn, and qqq only identifies two elements of nnn, and we can “rearrange” the elements of nnn in the middle in such a way that one of the elements identified by qqq is the one missed by jjj)

But then g(i)∘g(p)=g(f)=g(q)∘g(j)=g(q)∘g(σ)∘g(j)g(i) \circ g(p) = g(f) = g(q) \circ g(j) = g(q) \circ g(\sigma) \circ g(j)g(i)∘g(p)=g(f)=g(q)∘g(j)=g(q)∘g(σ)∘g(j) because g(σ)g(\sigma)g(σ) is the identity, and the latter is an isomorphism, which implies that g(i)g(i)g(i) is an isomorphism (it is injective by my “simple observation” and surjective because it has a section, namely g(p)g(p)g(p)), so g(n−1)=g(n−2)g(n-1) = g(n-2)g(n−1)=g(n−2).
Now, I thought I had an argument why this can be used to trigger an inductive step and show that ggg is “eventually constant” but perhaps I didn't :D
(Of course, it does work at least to show that if g(n)<ng(n) < ng(n)<n for all n≥Nn \geq Nn≥N, then g(n)=g(N−2)g(n) = g(N-2)g(n)=g(N−2) for all n≥N−2n \geq N-2n≥N−2)

Wow, this is cool but I'll need to think about it sometime when I'm not busy writing a math paper! Just to check: is it true that you are now only claiming that

If n≥5n \geq 5n≥5 and g(n)<ng(n) < ng(n)<n, then g(n−1)=g(n−2)g(n-1) = g(n-2)g(n−1)=g(n−2)

but not

If n≥5n \geq 5n≥5 and g(n)<ng(n) < ng(n)<n, then g(m)=g(n)g(m) = g(n)g(m)=g(n) for all m≥n−2m \geq n - 2m≥n−2.

?

Yes, that's correct, and what I am claiming implies

If N≥5N \geq 5N≥5 is such that g(n)<ng(n) < ng(n)<n for all n≥Nn \geq Nn≥N, then g(n)=g(N−2)g(n) = g(N-2)g(n)=g(N−2) for all n≥N−2n \geq N-2n≥N−2.

I think it should be possible to extend the argument as follows: for all k≥1k \geq 1k≥1 and m≥0m \geq 0m≥0 such that n:=3k+m≥5n := 3k + m \geq 5n:=3k+m≥5 and g(n)<ng(n) < ng(n)<n, we have g(k+m)=g(2k+m)g(k + m) = g(2k + m)g(k+m)=g(2k+m).

(The argument above is the case k=1k = 1k=1 and m=n−3m = n - 3m=n−3. For the generalisation, replace the injection i:n−2→n−1i: n - 2 \to n -1i:n−2→n−1 with an injection i:k+m→2k+mi: k + m \to 2k + mi:k+m→2k+m.)
I'm sure one can tweak it further...
On the other hand, this should be able to exclude John's example with k:=2k := 2k:=2 and m:=0m := 0m:=0, since g(6)=2<6g(6) = 2 < 6g(6)=2<6 but g(2)≠g(4)g(2) \neq g(4)g(2)=g(4).
Ok, I think I can instantiate this to a concrete counterexample to John's sequence.

We let

  • i:2→4i: 2 \to 4i:2→4 be defined by i(0)=0i(0) = 0i(0)=0 and i(1)=2i(1) = 2i(1)=2,
  • p:4→2p: 4 \to 2p:4→2 be defined by p(0)=p(1)=0p(0) = p(1) = 0p(0)=p(1)=0 and p(2)=p(3)=1p(2) = p(3) = 1p(2)=p(3)=1,
  • j:4→6j: 4 \to 6j:4→6 be defined by j(0)=0j(0) = 0j(0)=0, j(1)=1j(1) = 1j(1)=1, j(2)=3j(2) = 3j(2)=3, j(3)=4j(3) = 4j(3)=4,
  • q:6→4q: 6 \to 4q:6→4 be defined by q(0)=q(1)=0q(0) = q(1) = 0q(0)=q(1)=0, q(2)=1q(2) = 1q(2)=1, q(3)=q(4)=2q(3) = q(4) = 2q(3)=q(4)=2, q(5)=3q(5) = 3q(5)=3,
  • σ:6→6\sigma: 6 \to 6σ:6→6 be the even permutation (12)(45)(12)(45)(12)(45)
Then we have i∘p=q∘j:4→4i \circ p = q \circ j: 4 \to 4i∘p=q∘j:4→4, and q∘σ∘jq \circ \sigma \circ jq∘σ∘j is equal to the identity on 444.
Since ggg induces a homomorphism S6→Sg(6)=S2S_6 \to S_{g(6)} = S_2S6​→Sg(6)​=S2​, and the kernel of this homomorphism must contain A6A_6A6​, g(σ)g(\sigma)g(σ) is the identity on 2.

It follows that g(i)∘g(p)=g(q)∘g(j)=g(q)∘g(σ)∘g(j)=g(q∘σ∘j)=g(id4)=id2g(i) \circ g(p) = g(q) \circ g(j) = g(q) \circ g(\sigma) \circ g(j) = g(q \circ \sigma \circ j) = g(\mathrm{id}_4) = \mathrm{id}_2g(i)∘g(p)=g(q)∘g(j)=g(q)∘g(σ)∘g(j)=g(q∘σ∘j)=g(id4​)=id2​, but then g(i):g(2)=1→g(4)=2g(i): g(2) = 1 \to g(4) = 2g(i):g(2)=1→g(4)=2 has g(p)g(p)g(p) as a section, which is impossible.

Btw this is how I think of the functions p,i,j,q,σp, i, j, q, \sigmap,i,j,q,σ graphically, seeing F\mathsf{F}F as the symmetric monoidal category generated by a commutative monoid.

.be58628b-773d-4cb3-966c-b89bd273ff45.jpg
(σ\sigmaσ should have mmm wires at the right end which I forgot to draw)

Conjecture: Every bounded endofunctor of FinSet\mathsf{FinSet}FinSet is constant on all nonempty sets (and morphisms between them). Equivalently, every such functor is a finite coproduct of the terminal functor (which sends everything to 1) and the subterminal functor which maps ∅↦1\emptyset \mapsto 1∅↦1 and takes everything else to ∅\emptyset∅.
Does this look plausible now? It's possible that I'm missing some obvious counterexample.

It's a bit annoying that the empty set plays a special role: a functor F:FinSet→FinSetF : \mathsf{FinSet} \to \mathsf{FinSet}F:FinSet→FinSet can be pretty arbitrary on the empty set, which doesn't have any morphisms into it. So maybe it would be more elegant to remove the empty set from FinSet\mathsf{FinSet}FinSet? Like this, the conjecture is that every bounded functor FinSet∖∅→FinSet\mathsf{FinSet}\setminus \emptyset \to \mathsf{FinSet}FinSet∖∅→FinSet is a finite coproduct of the terminal functor with itself.
(I've corrected a silly error in the conjecture and comments.)

One more consequence of my earlier observation: if ggg is bounded, then eventually (when nnn is strictly larger than the bound) g(n)<ng(n) < ng(n)<n, so ggg is eventually constant.

What is the eventual value of ggg? Well, let N:=min⁡{m∣g(n)<n for all n≥m}N := \min \{ m \mid g(n) < n \text{ for all } n \geq m \}N:=min{m∣g(n)<n for all n≥m}.
Then ggg is constant after N−2N-2N−2 with value g(N−2)g(N-2)g(N−2). But g(N−1)=g(N)<Ng(N-1) = g(N) < Ng(N−1)=g(N)<N, yet g(N−1)≥N−1g(N-1) \geq N-1g(N−1)≥N−1 by definition of NNN. It follows that g(N−1)=N−1g(N-1) = N-1g(N−1)=N−1, that is, the eventual value of ggg is N−1N-1N−1.
(I guess this needs NNN to be at least 5 for my argument to apply)
Do you know of any examples that are eventually constant, but not actually constant (on nonempty sets)?
No, I think your conjecture sounds very plausible, I'm trying to make steps towards proving it.
This says that if ggg is eventually constant with value m≥4m \geq 4m≥4, it must have already stabilised at m−1m-1m−1, so it restricts how "long" such an endofunctor can vary...

I'm probably being dense, but doesn't eventually constant in particular mean that the functor ggg takes every constant map n→nn \to nn→n (with sufficiently large nnn) to the identity? Then since splitting of idempotents is an absolute (co)limit, it would follow that g(1)=g(n)g(1) = g(n)g(1)=g(n)?

I mean that a constant map n→nn \to nn→n is an idempotent that is split by 111, and ggg must preserve this splitting. But if ggg sends the constant map to the identity, then we get g(1)≅g(n)g(1) \cong g(n)g(1)≅g(n).

If the goal is merely to prove (g(n))n(g(n))_n(g(n))n​ eventually constant when bounded, since it is not decreasing as Amar observed, it is already implied by the usual properties of sequences of natural numbers.

Right, every bounded monotone sequence of natural numbers is eventually constant. But I think what we'd like to have is the stronger statement that such a functor ggg is an eventually constant functor, meaning that it takes every map between sufficiently large sets to one and the same identity map. (This is in terms of language assuming a skeleton, as John suggested originally.) Is this obvious as well?

Yes I agree, I specifically did not say anything about morphisms because I did not have anything relevant to say about that, I don't think it is obvious at all. The only thing I can say is that if ggg is always constant on objects, then it sends epis and monos to iso (for cardinality reasons again), thus every map to an iso (by the epi-mono factorisation). I have no idea how to show that these isos are always the identity

Ha, actually they're not always identity! Because even with functors F→F\mathsf{F} \to \mathsf{F}F→F, where F\mathsf{F}F is a skeleton of FinSet\mathsf{FinSet}FinSet, we still can have 'constant' functors that act like g(n)=kg(n) = kg(n)=k for fixed kkk on objects, and as g(f:n→m)=σmσn−1g(f : n \to m) = \sigma_m \sigma_n^{-1}g(f:n→m)=σm​σn−1​, where σn∈F(k,k)\sigma_n \in \mathsf{F}(k, k)σn​∈F(k,k) is an arbitrary sequence of automorphisms, on morphisms.
These are precisely the functors that are naturally isomorphic to functors that are actually constant in the sense of mapping every morphism to an identity.
So I suppose the right definition of 'constant functor' is a functor that is naturally isomorphic to one which sends all morphisms to one and the same identity morphism.
Your conjectured Liouville’s theorem for FinSet is very beautiful, @Tobias Fritz!

Among the many Liousville's theorems, I suppose you're referring to the complex analysis one, @Kevin Carlson ? That's a really interesting analogy actually, because maybe there is some connection with analytic functors (about which I know nothing)?
Yes, I was struck by how much it sounds like “every bounded complex analytic function is constant.”
Conceivably there is a relation, but I also have no idea.

Maybe linked to some differential linear logic (although you very probably don't need any of this to prove your conjecture) :smirk:

Marcelo Fiore, Nicola Gambino, Martin Hyland, Monoidal bicategories, differential linear logic, and analytic functors: arXiv:2405.05774
Maybe there exists a differential linear logic Liouville theorem and this conjecture as well as the theorem in complex analysis would be special cases of it :smirk:
But don't worry about this, I just write it for me :face_in_clouds:

Amar Hadzihasanovic said:

How is I a functor on F? We have Inj(3,3)=3! but Inj(3,1)=∅, so there can be no way to interpret Ip for p:3→1 the only functio

Oops, yes; thanks. That I warned that the quality of my response might be affected by having just woken up now seems prescient (and I should listen to such warnings!). Oh, well.
Ok, I think I can improve my earlier argument to prove Tobias's conjecture.

Suppose ggg is bounded, so it is eventually constant with value NNN.
Let m≥1m \geq 1m≥1, and pick k≥0k \geq 0k≥0 such that g(2k+m)=Ng(2k + m) = Ng(2k+m)=N and g(4k+m)<4k+mg(4k + m) < 4k + mg(4k+m)<4k+m; this is always possible by picking kkk large enough.

Then define the following functions:

  • i:m→2k+mi: m \to 2k + mi:m→2k+m by i(j):=ji(j) := ji(j):=j for all j∈{0,…,m−1}j \in \{0, \ldots, m-1\}j∈{0,…,m−1},
  • p:2k+m→mp: 2k + m \to mp:2k+m→m by p(j):=jp(j) := jp(j):=j for j∈{0,…,m−1}j \in \{0, \ldots, m-1 \}j∈{0,…,m−1} and p(j):=m−1p(j) := m-1p(j):=m−1 for j∈{m,…,2k+m−1}j \in \{m, \ldots, 2k + m - 1\}j∈{m,…,2k+m−1},
  • q:2k+m→4k+mq: 2k + m \to 4k + mq:2k+m→4k+m by q(j):=jq(j) := jq(j):=j for all j∈{0,…,2k+m−1}j \in \{0, \ldots, 2k + m - 1\}j∈{0,…,2k+m−1},
  • ℓ:4k+m→2k+m\ell: 4k + m \to 2k + mℓ:4k+m→2k+m by ℓ(j):=j\ell(j) := jℓ(j):=j for j∈{0,…,m−1}j \in \{0, \ldots, m-1 \}j∈{0,…,m−1}, ℓ(j):=m−1\ell(j) := m-1ℓ(j):=m−1 for j∈{m,…,2k+m−1}j \in \{m, \ldots, 2k + m - 1\}j∈{m,…,2k+m−1}, and ℓ(j):=j−2k\ell(j) := j - 2kℓ(j):=j−2k for j∈{2k+m,…,4k+m−1}j \in \{2k + m, \ldots, 4k + m - 1\}j∈{2k+m,…,4k+m−1},
  • σ:4k+m→4k+m\sigma: 4k + m \to 4k + mσ:4k+m→4k+m is the permutation exchanging m+jm + jm+j and 2k+m+j2k + m + j2k+m+j for all j∈{0,…,2k−1}j \in \{0, \ldots, 2k - 1\}j∈{0,…,2k−1}.

Notice that σ\sigmaσ is the product of 2k2k2k transpositions so it is even.
Then, as in the earlier argument, we have i∘p=q∘ℓi \circ p = q \circ \elli∘p=q∘ℓ but q∘σ∘ℓ=id2k+mq \circ \sigma \circ \ell = \mathrm{id}_{2k+m}q∘σ∘ℓ=id2k+m​.

Moreover, by the same argument as before about homomorphisms of symmetric groups, g(σ)=idg(4k+m)g(\sigma) = \mathrm{id}_{g(4k+m)}g(σ)=idg(4k+m)​.

It follows that g(i∘p)=g(i)∘g(p)=idg(2k+m)g(i \circ p) = g(i) \circ g(p) = \mathrm{id}_{g(2k+m)}g(i∘p)=g(i)∘g(p)=idg(2k+m)​, which implies that g(i):g(m)→g(2k+m)=Ng(i): g(m) \to g(2k +m) = Ng(i):g(m)→g(2k+m)=N is an isomorphism, so g(m)=Ng(m) = Ng(m)=N.
Because m≥1m \geq 1m≥1 was arbitrary, ggg is constant with value NNN on non-empty sets.

As Tobias was noting, ggg can do what it wants on 000 and the unique function 0→10 \to 10→1, and can send functions between non-empty sets to arbitrary automorphisms of NNN.

This is because we can always apply the unit of the adjunction between preorders and categories to F\mathsf{F}F, which sends it to the preorder 0<1≃2≃…≃n≃…0 < 1 \simeq 2 \simeq \ldots \simeq n \simeq \ldots0<1≃2≃…≃n≃…, and then a functor from this preorder to F\mathsf{F}F is exactly a choice of a function g(0)→g(1)=Ng(0) \to g(1) = Ng(0)→g(1)=N and an arbitrary sequence of automorphisms of NNN.

I half-remember some result about endofunctors of FinSet and absolutely monotonic sequences. A sequence is absolutely monotonic if its differences ai+1−aia_{i+1} - a_iai+1​−ai​ are all positive, and the differences of its differences, and so on. I can't remember the result or find a reference though. Perhaps it was that all such sequences extend to functors?

In fact as we have seen we can relax "bounded" to "eventually sub-identity", that is, the stronger statement is the following:

Suppose g:F→Fg: \mathsf{F} \to \mathsf{F}g:F→F is an endofunctor. If there exists mmm such that, for all n≥mn \geq mn≥m, g(n)<ng(n) < ng(n)<n, then ggg is constant on non-empty sets.

Oscar Cunningham said:

I half-remember some result about endofunctors of FinSet and absolutely monotonic sequences. A sequence is absolutely monotonic if its differences ai+1−aia_{i+1} - a_iai+1​−ai​ are all positive, and the differences of its differences, and so on. I can't remember the result or find a reference though. Perhaps it was that all such sequences extend to functors?

maybe you are referring to this paper , the Theorem 1.2 indeed gives a sufficient and necessary condition involving the iterated differences!
Oh that's too bad, so the question has already been answered completely :D

Very nice find! There seems to be a fun story behind that paper:

I would like to thank George Bergman for suggesting this problem (on a
homework assignment—I did not get much other homework done in that course)

This sequence is defined in a fairly simple purely combinatorial way, where the nth term involves the free shelf on n elements. A shelf is a set with a binary operation that distributes over itself.

For details of how the sequence is defined, go here:

  • John Baez, Shelves and the infinite

It looks like this sequence increases to 16 and then stops, but assuming the existence of an extremely large cardinal, called a 'I3 rank-into-rank cardinal' Richard Laver showed in the late 1980s that it grows unboundedly! My article gives a simple explanation of what an I3 rank-into-rank cardinal is.

So, this is an extremely slow-growing sequence whose basic properties may go beyond what we can study in ZFC without extra axioms.

What Randall Dougherty did is prove a lower bound on how far you have to go into the sequence before it increases beyond 16. His lower bound was A(9,A(8,A(8,255))) where A(-,-) is a certain two-variable Ackermann function.
So, Dougherty is the kind of guy who can sink his teeth into really hard combinatorial problems and not let go.
We should not feel bad that he beat us to the solution of this problem. Thanks for finding his paper, @Clémence Chanavat!

I (shamefully) can't read the theorems: do they also solve the conjecture about bounded analytic functors?

This seems to follow relatively easily once the definition is known: an endofunctor of FinSet is

  • near-representable when it is a quotient of a representable functor 𝐲n𝐲ₙyn​ by some subgroup of the automorphism group 𝔖n𝔖ₙSn​ of nnn, and
  • analytic when it is a pointwise coproduct of near-representable functors.

In order to land in FinSet, such coproducts need to be finite.

Let us now consider any bounded, analytic endofunctor F≅∐i𝐲ni/GiF \cong \coprod_i 𝐲_{nᵢ}/{Gᵢ}F≅∐i​yni​​/Gi​ on FinSet, where 𝐲n/G𝐲_n/{G}yn​/G denotes the quotient of 𝐲n𝐲ₙyn​ by the subgroup GGG of 𝔖n𝔖ₙSn​.

For any non-empty nnn and subgroup GGG of 𝔖n𝔖ₙSn​, 𝐲n/G𝐲ₙ/{G}yn​/G cannot be bounded, so all ninᵢni​'s are empty and FFF is constant.

Am I making any sense?

Tom Hirschowitz said:

I (shamefully) can't read the theorems: do they also solve the conjecture about bounded analytic functors?

Which theorems can't you read? Let me tell you Dougherty's theorem about which sequences are functorial.
This mathoverflow question seems to be related to the discussion https://mathoverflow.net/questions/346290/when-is-an-integer-sequence-the-trace-of-a-monad-on-finset

Let's say a function a:N→Na : \mathbb{N} \to \mathbb{N}a:N→N is functorial if there's some functor g:FinSet→FinSetg: \mathsf{FinSet} \to \mathsf{FinSet}g:FinSet→FinSet that sends each set with nnn elements to a set with a(n)a(n)a(n) elements.

Dougherty's Theorem 1.2 gives necessary and sufficient conditions for a function a:N→Na : \mathbb{N} \to \mathbb{N}a:N→N to be functorial.

We've seen that the case a(0)a(0)a(0) is funny, so Dougherty allows us to tweak that value:

Theorem. A function a:N→Na : \mathbb{N} \to \mathbb{N}a:N→N is functorial if and only if there exists a positive integer r≤a(1)r \le a(1)r≤a(1) such that if we define a new function b:N→Nb: \mathbb{N} \to \mathbb{N}b:N→N with

b(0)=rb(0) = rb(0)=r
b(n)=a(n)b(n) = a(n)b(n)=a(n) for n>0n \gt 0n>0

then

(Δkb)(0)≥0(\Delta^k b)(0) \ge 0 (Δkb)(0)≥0

for all k=0,1,2,...k = 0, 1, 2, ...k=0,1,2,....

Here Δ\DeltaΔ is the difference operator, defined on functions f:N→Nf: \mathbb{N} \to \mathbb{N}f:N→N by

(Δf)(n)=f(n+1)−f(n) (\Delta f)(n) = f(n+1) - f(n) (Δf)(n)=f(n+1)−f(n)

Δk \Delta^kΔk is the kkk th power of that operator, e.g.

(Δ2f)(n)=f(n+2)−2f(n+1)+f(n) (\Delta^2 f)(n) = f(n+2) - 2 f(n+1) + f(n) (Δ2f)(n)=f(n+2)−2f(n+1)+f(n)

Now, it's possible that since we know the theorem, we can prove it more beautifully than Dougherty did, using more category theory.

Here's an obvious question: can we categorify the difference operator?

Given a functor g:FinSet→FinSetg : \mathsf{FinSet} \to \mathsf{FinSet}g:FinSet→FinSet, can we find a functor

Δg:FinSet→FinSet \Delta g : \mathsf{FinSet} \to \mathsf{FinSet}Δg:FinSet→FinSet

such that

g(n+1)≅g(n)+(Δg)(n) g(n+1) \cong g(n) + (\Delta g)(n) g(n+1)≅g(n)+(Δg)(n) ?

It would be nicest if this isomorphism were a natural isomorphism, but we don't even need that for this to imply that

∣g(n+1)∣≥∣g(n)∣ |g(n+1)| \ge |g(n)| ∣g(n+1)∣≥∣g(n)∣

I feel that what I'm asking is closely related to Amar's slick proof that any functorial sequence is nondecreasing:

Amar Hadzihasanovic said:

One simple observation is that because all epimorphisms/monomorphisms between non-empty sets in F\mathsf{F}F are split, they must be preserved by ggg. And because in F\mathsf{F}F there exists a (split) mono from nnn to mmm if and only if n≤mn \leq mn≤m, it follows that n↦g(n)n \mapsto g(n)n↦g(n) must be a non-decreasing sequence for all n≥1n \geq 1n≥1.

Unfortunately while Amar's argument here shows there is a (split) mono from g(n)g(n)g(n) to g(n+1)g(n+1)g(n+1), it doesn't seem to give a natural mono g(n)→g(n+1)g(n) \to g(n+1)g(n)→g(n+1), much less a functor that plays the role of Δg\Delta gΔg, namely

"(Δg)(n)=g(n+1)−g(n)(\Delta g)(n) = g(n+1) - g(n) (Δg)(n)=g(n+1)−g(n)"

with quotes because subtraction involves a choice of splitting.

Hmm, here's a weird idea: we just drop the requirement that Δg\Delta gΔg be a functor! We just define it as some map from finite sets to finite sets. It will still have the property that the cardinality of (Δg)(n)(\Delta g)(n)(Δg)(n) is nonnegative, which is enough to ensure the cardinalities ∣g(n)∣|g(n)|∣g(n)∣ are increasing. But are we then able to define Δ2g\Delta^2 gΔ2g, or do we get stuck? Dougherty's theorem seems to imply that Δk\Delta^kΔk is a good thing to study for all k=0,1,2,....k = 0 , 1, 2, ....k=0,1,2,....
@John Baez Is that really all that Dougherty's theorem says? It looks like there's some more stuff about the function he calls Φ\PhiΦ.

@John Baez One thought I have is whether it is worth thinking about endofunctors of finite sets and partial functions, first; let's call their category P\mathsf{P}P.

There is a free-forgetful adjunction between F\mathsf{F}F and P\mathsf{P}P, where the latter is seen as the Kleisli category of the −+1- + 1−+1 (maybe) monad on F\mathsf{F}F, so in a certain sense any endofunctor of one can be transported to the other along the adjunction.

Now, suppose ggg is an endofunctor on P\mathsf{P}P. There is a pointed endofunctor −+1- + 1−+1 on P\mathsf{P}P, with natural inclusions ηn:n→n+1\eta_n: n \to n + 1ηn​:n→n+1 which are total injective functions.
I would propose defining Δg\Delta gΔg as sending

  • nnn to the complement of the image of g(ηn):g(n)→g(n+1)g(\eta_n): g(n) \to g(n + 1)g(ηn​):g(n)→g(n+1) in g(n+1)g(n + 1)g(n+1),
  • a partial function f:n→mf: n \to mf:n→m to the partial function obtained by restricting g(f+1)g(f + 1)g(f+1) to Δg(n)\Delta g(n)Δg(n) and “corestricting” it to Δg(m)\Delta g(m)Δg(m), that is, making the restriction undefined whenever the image of an element is not in Δg(m)\Delta g(m)Δg(m).

It seems plausible to me that this is in fact an endofunctor on P\mathsf{P}P, although I haven't checked carefully -- by naturality of ηn\eta_nηn​, it is at least true that g(f+1)g(f + 1)g(f+1) maps the image of g(ηn)g(\eta_n)g(ηn​) to the image of g(ηm)g(\eta_m)g(ηm​), which prevents an element from “leaving” Δg\Delta gΔg and then “returning” to it -- this would disrupt functoriality.

By construction, this would satisfy g(n+1)=g(n)+Δg(n)g(n+1) = g(n) + \Delta g(n)g(n+1)=g(n)+Δg(n).

ADDENDUM: ...as long as g(ηn)g(\eta_n)g(ηn​) is total and injective. I think these should both always be true as long as ηn\eta_nηn​ is a split mono, which is true when n≥1n \geq 1n≥1.

Otherwise, perhaps we have to restrict to ggg sending 0→10 \to 10→1 to a total injective function? (Again what endofunctors do on 0 seems to be always a sticking point.)

So, if this is correct, let F:F→PF: \mathsf{F} \to \mathsf{P}F:F→P and U:P→FU: \mathsf{P} \to \mathsf{F}U:P→F be the left and right adjoint functors, and suppose ggg is an endofunctor on F\mathsf{F}F.

Then we get an endofunctor FgUFgUFgU on P\mathsf{P}P, which at the level of objects sends nnn to g(n+1)g(n + 1)g(n+1), so there is just a “shift by 1” of everything -- this may hint at why 0 is a bit of a special case...

And then for this endofunctor we can take a “functorial difference”, which gives another endofunctor on P\mathsf{P}P. The fact that this can be iterated would explain why all the iterated differences must be positive.

Oscar Cunningham said:

John Baez Is that really all that Dougherty's theorem says? It looks like there's some more stuff about the function he calls Φ\PhiΦ.

Oh, ugh! You're right. I thought conditions (1) and (2) were equivalent characterizations of functorial sequences but he says a sequence is functorial if one or the other of these conditions hold. Condition (1) is the one I stated, and condition (2) is more complicated and involves something called Φ\PhiΦ.
Since I don't want to think about condition (2) right now, I'd be happy to show that condition (1) implies functoriality, i.e.:

We say a function a:N→Na : \mathbb{N} \to \mathbb{N}a:N→N is functorial if there's some functor g:FinSet→FinSetg: \mathsf{FinSet} \to \mathsf{FinSet}g:FinSet→FinSet that sends each set with nnn elements to a set with a(n)a(n)a(n) elements.

Theorem. A function a:N→Na : \mathbb{N} \to \mathbb{N}a:N→N is functorial if there exists a positive integer r≤a(1)r \le a(1)r≤a(1) such that if we define a new function b:N→Nb: \mathbb{N} \to \mathbb{N}b:N→N with

b(0)=rb(0) = rb(0)=r
b(n)=a(n)b(n) = a(n)b(n)=a(n) for n>0n \gt 0n>0

then

(Δkb)(0)≥0(\Delta^k b)(0) \ge 0 (Δkb)(0)≥0

for all k∈Nk \in \mathbb{N}k∈N, where Δ\DeltaΔ is the difference operator, defined on functions f:N→Nf: \mathbb{N} \to \mathbb{N}f:N→N by

(Δf)(n)=f(n+1)−f(n) (\Delta f)(n) = f(n+1) - f(n) (Δf)(n)=f(n+1)−f(n)

This picture should illustrate why Δg\Delta gΔg is functorial on partial functions...
Screenshot-from-2024-08-16-16-54-27.png
Some of the elements of Δg(n)\Delta g(n)Δg(n) may be mapped by g(f+1)g(f+1)g(f+1) to elements of g(m)g(m)g(m) resulting in Δg(f)\Delta g(f)Δg(f) being undefined on them, but once they are, they “stay there”.

So Δg(h∘f)\Delta g(h \circ f)Δg(h∘f) is completely specified by the pair of Δg(h)\Delta g(h)Δg(h) and Δg(f)\Delta g(f)Δg(f).

The fact that g(n)g(n)g(n) can be identified with its image through g(ηn)g(\eta_n)g(ηn​) in g(n+1)g(n+1)g(n+1) relies on g(ηn)g(\eta_n)g(ηn​) being total and injective, which is ensured by ηn\eta_nηn​ being a split mono when n≥1n \geq 1n≥1, but probably needs to be made an extra assumption for η0\eta_0η0​.

By the way this “extra assumption” looks very similar to the fact that the sequence aaa needs to be “redefined” on 0 so that b(0)≤b(1)b(0) \leq b(1)b(0)≤b(1) in the theorem we are looking at!

(But even if that is not true of ggg, the only thing that changes is that g(1)=img(η0)+Δg(0)g(1) = \mathrm{im} g(\eta_0) + \Delta g(0)g(1)=img(η0​)+Δg(0), where the image of g(η0)g(\eta_0)g(η0​) may be smaller than g(0)g(0)g(0) itself).

So if I haven't made any mistakes, I'm claiming the following:

Let P\mathsf{P}P be the category of finite sets and partial functions and let ggg be an endofunctor on P\mathsf{P}P.

Then there exists an endofunctor Δg\Delta gΔg on P\mathsf{P}P which, for all n≥1n \geq 1n≥1, satisfies g(n+1)=g(n)+Δg(n)g(n+1) = g(n) + \Delta g(n)g(n+1)=g(n)+Δg(n) at the level of objects.

Moreover, if η:0→1\eta: 0 \to 1η:0→1 is the only (partial) function of its type, and g(η)g(\eta)g(η) is total and injective, then also g(1)=g(0)+Δg(0)g(1) = g(0) + \Delta g(0)g(1)=g(0)+Δg(0).

Moreover,

Let ggg be an endofunctor on F\mathsf{F}F, the category of finite sets and functions.
Then there exists an endofunctor g^\hat{g}g^​ on P\mathsf{P}P which satisfies g^(n)=g(n+1)\hat{g}(n) = g(n+1)g^​(n)=g(n+1) for all n≥0n \geq 0n≥0 at the level of objects.

Moreover, this endofunctor is such that g^(η)\hat{g}(\eta)g^​(η) is total and injective.

Dually,

Proof: define gˉ\bar{g}gˉ​ as UgFUgFUgF.

I feel like I should be able to combine these facts in a way that proves that iterated difference operators on g(n)g(n)g(n) are positive at least on n≥1n \geq 1n≥1, but I am getting tired and I am struggling to find the best way, so I will stop here for now :D
For this delta operator, please see the last paper by Pare on the arxiv and it might be relevant for the functor to be (thought as) taut, otherwise, a good notion of difference is not well defined.

I realised that, unlike in F\mathsf{F}F, in P\mathsf{P}P the unique function from 000 to any other object is also a split monomorphism, whose left inverse is the totally undefined partial function, so the extra assumption was unnecessary. The simpler statement is:

Let P\mathsf{P}P be the category of finite sets and partial functions and let ggg be an endofunctor on P\mathsf{P}P.

Then there exists an endofunctor Δg\Delta gΔg on P\mathsf{P}P which for all n≥0n \geq 0n≥0 satisfies g(n+1)=g(n)+Δg(n)g(n+1) = g(n) + \Delta g(n)g(n+1)=g(n)+Δg(n) at the level of objects.

Iterating this construction, this means that, if an:=g(n)a_n := g(n)an​:=g(n) as a sequence of natural numbers, we do have, for all k,n≥0k, n \geq 0k,n≥0, that Δkan≥0\Delta^k a_n \geq 0Δkan​≥0.

Now if ggg is an endofunctor of F\mathsf{F}F, with associated sequence an:=g(n)a_n := g(n)an​:=g(n), we have seen that there is an endofunctor g^\hat{g}g^​ of P\mathsf{P}P whose associated sequence is a^n:=an+1\hat{a}_n := a_{n+1}a^n​:=an+1​.

It follows that:

Let F\mathsf{F}F be the category of finite sets and functions, let ggg be an endofunctor on F\mathsf{F}F, and let an:=g(n)a_n := g(n)an​:=g(n) as a sequence of natural numbers.

Then for all k≥0k \geq 0k≥0 and n≥1n \geq 1n≥1, it holds that Δkan≥0\Delta^k a_n \geq 0Δkan​≥0.

I'd conjecture that the sufficient condition can also be simplified for endofunctors on P\mathsf{P}P, that is, a sequence ana_nan​ is functorial wrt P\mathsf{P}P if and only if Δka0≥0\Delta^k a_0 \geq 0Δka0​≥0 for all k≥0k \geq 0k≥0.

I think the double (contravariant) powerset functor (adapted to P\mathsf{P}P) should be a counterexample.

So

  • g(n)g(n)g(n) is the set of families F\mathcal{F}F of subsets S⊆n={0,…,n−1}S \subseteq n = \{0, \ldots, n-1\}S⊆n={0,…,n−1},
  • given f:n→mf: n \to mf:n→m, g(f)g(f)g(f) sends F\mathcal{F}F to {T⊆m∣f−1T∈F}\{T \subseteq m \mid f^{-1}T \in \mathcal{F} \}{T⊆m∣f−1T∈F},
  • Δg(n)\Delta g(n)Δg(n) is the subset of g(n+1)g(n+1)g(n+1) on families F\mathcal{F}F such that at least one S∈FS \in \mathcal{F}S∈F contains nnn.

Let f:2→1f: 2 \to 1f:2→1 be the only total function of its type, and let F:={{0,2}}∈g(3)\mathcal{F} := \{ \{0, 2 \} \} \in g(3)F:={{0,2}}∈g(3).
Then F∈Δg(2)\mathcal{F} \in \Delta g(2)F∈Δg(2), but g(f+1)(F)=∅∉Δg(1)g(f + 1)(\mathcal{F}) = \varnothing \not\in \Delta g(1)g(f+1)(F)=∅∈Δg(1), because there is no subset of 222 whose inverse image through f+1f + 1f+1 is {0,2}\{0, 2\}{0,2}.

So Δg(f)\Delta g(f)Δg(f) must be undefined on F\mathcal{F}F, but g(f+1)g(f + 1)g(f+1) is everywhere defined, so g(−+1)g(- + 1)g(−+1) does not split into g+Δgg + \Delta gg+Δg.
(I looked at the double powerset after @Ivan Di Liberti's suggestion, since it is an example of a functor that is not taut).
I've been trying to catch up on this a bit, and wonder if there's a simple explanation of why tautness is relevant?
Given a taut endofunctor on F\mathsf{F}F, does this imply that it can be extended to P\mathsf{P}P? Could this be what's going on?

@Tobias Fritz Well, the idea is that the difference operator is always well-defined on endofunctors on P\mathsf{P}P, so in particular one can take an endofunctor of F\mathsf{F}F, transport it to an endofunctor of P\mathsf{P}P using g↦FgUg \mapsto FgUg↦FgU, and apply Δ\DeltaΔ on there. But Δ(FgU)=F(Δg)U\Delta (F g U) = F (\Delta g) UΔ(FgU)=F(Δg)U for some endofunctor Δg\Delta gΔg of F\mathsf{F}F if (and only if?) ggg is taut.
(Doubt the “only if” part, since only very specific inverse images have to be preserved in order for Δg\Delta gΔg to be well-defined.)

On the other hand, since the sequence of FgUFgUFgU is just the sequence of ggg shifted by one, it seems to me that one can make the argument about iterated differences more cleanly by working with P\mathsf{P}P, and the “shift by one” explains why the value of the sequence at 000 may need to be readjusted in Dougherty's condition.

Amar Hadzihasanovic said:

But Δ(FgU)=F(Δg)U\Delta (F g U) = F (\Delta g) UΔ(FgU)=F(Δg)U for some endofunctor Δg\Delta gΔg of F\mathsf{F}F if (and only if?) ggg is taut.

Excellent, thanks, that's what I've been wondering. This seems interesting independently of the current discussion, as it may help explain the significance of tautness more broadly.
